doc.field: Areas of Predicted Aquifer Decline Greater than 50% of Available Head - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota
Areas of Predicted Aquifer Decline Greater than 50% of Available Head - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota

This dataset illustrates areas where 2030 and 2050 projected aquifer drawdown in currently confined portions of the Prairie du Chien-Jordan and Franconia-Ironton-Galesville aquifers is expected to reduce available head by more than 50% within the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Reductions in available head greater than 50% may signal future water supply limitations if aquifer withdrawals continue to increase. Aquifer drawdown was predicted using Metropolitan Council water demand projections and a regional groundwater flow model of the Twin Cities metropolitan area (Metro Model 2) developed for the Council by Barr Engineering Company.
More information about this process is provided in the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan', which is available online at www.metrocouncil.org/environment/WaterSupply/metrogroundwatermodeldatasets.htm.

<?xml version="1.0"?><metadata> <idinfo> <citation> <citeinfo> <title>Areas of Predicted Aquifer Decline Greater than 50% of Available Head - Twin Cities Metropolitan Area, Minnesota</title> <origin>Metropolitan Council</origin> <pubinfo> <publish>Metropolitan Council</publish> </pubinfo> <pubdate>20091201</pubdate> <onlink>ftp://gisftp.metc.state.mn.us/GroundwaterModelResults.zip</onlink> </citeinfo> </citation> <descript> <abstract>This dataset illustrates areas where 2030 and 2050 projected aquifer drawdown in currently confined portions of the Prairie du Chien-Jordan and Franconia-Ironton-Galesville aquifers is expected to reduce available head by more than 50% within the Twin Cities metropolitan area. Reductions in available head greater than 50% may signal future water supply limitations if aquifer withdrawals continue to increase. Aquifer drawdown was predicted using Metropolitan Council water demand projections and a regional groundwater flow model of the Twin Cities metropolitan area (Metro Model 2) developed for the Council by Barr Engineering Company.
More information about this process is provided in the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan', which is available online at www.metrocouncil.org/environment/WaterSupply/metrogroundwatermodeldatasets.htm.</abstract> <purpose>The 2005 Minnesota Legislature directed the Metropolitan Council to "carry out planning activities addressing the water supply needs of the metropolitan area" (Minnesota Statutes, Section 473.1565). Specifically the Council is charged with developing a base of technical information for water supply planning decisions and to prepare a metropolitan area master water supply plan. This dataset supports this charge.</purpose> <supplinf>Twin Cities metropolitan area including the counties of Anoka, Carver, Dakota, Hennepin, Ramsey, Scott and Washington in Minnesota</supplinf> </descript> <timeperd> <timeinfo> <sngdate> <caldate>20091201</caldate> </sngdate> </timeinfo> <current>Data is based upon Metropolitan Council population projections developed in 2006 and a regional groundwater flow model calibration completed in Spring 2009.</current> </timeperd> <status> <progress>Complete</progress> <update>As Needed</update> </status> <keywords> <place> <placekey>Twin Cities, Anoka County, Carver County, Dakota County, Hennepin County, Ramsey County, Scott County, Washington County, Minnesota</placekey> </place> <theme> <themekey>water supply planning, available head, Prairie du Chien-Jordan, Franconia-Ironton-Galesville, Metro Model 2, groundwater</themekey> </theme> </keywords> <accconst>None</accconst> <useconst>By acceptance of this data, the user agrees to include a copy of the metadata record, including the liability disclaimer, whenever the user transmits or provides the GIS data (or any portion of it) to another user.</useconst> <browse> <browsen>None available</browsen> <browsed /> </browse> <crossref> <citeinfo> <title>Datasets described by this metadata:
drawhdfra2030 drawhdfra2050 drawhdpdc2030 drawhdpdc2050</title> </citeinfo> </crossref> <native>Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 2; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.2.1.1332</native> <ptcontac> <cntinfo> <cntperp> <cntorg>Metropolitan Council</cntorg> <cntper>Lanya Ross</cntper> </cntperp> <cntpos>Sr. Environmental Scientist, Water Supply Planning</cntpos> <cntaddr> <address>390 Robert St. North</address> <city>St Paul</city> <state>MN</state> <postal>55101-1805</postal> </cntaddr> <cntvoice>651-602-1066</cntvoice> <cntfax>651-602-1130</cntfax> <cntemail>lanya.ross@metc.state.mn.us</cntemail> </cntinfo> </ptcontac> </idinfo> <dataqual> <attracc> <attraccr>The absolute residual mean (mean error) of the regional groundwater flow model is 5.03 meters (16.50 feet). Models are abstract approximations of reality; therefore, all models have inherent uncertainty imbedded within them. This uncertainty within the model will always lead to some uncertainty in any predictions made by the model. Sources of uncertainty in the Metro Model 2 stem from:
- An incomplete understanding of the geologic conditions in the Twin Cities area, including the presence of undetected features (e.g., faults, changes in glacial deposits);
- An incomplete understanding of groundwater flow conditions in the Twin Cities;
- Data gaps in groundwater levels (particularly for deeper aquifers);
- Data gaps on the hydraulic conductivity of the aquifers and aquitard due to a small set of existing pumping tests;
- Undocumented or unreported groundwater withdrawals;
- Limited base-flow data for streams (particularly for the Mississippi River through Minneapolis and St. Paul);
- Limited or non-existent information on the permeability of lake bottoms;
- The necessary simplifications, lumping of conditions, and time-averaging of observations that is needed in order to build and calibrate a groundwater flow model;
- Incomplete and evolving understanding of how and where recharge through infiltration takes place;
- The need to exclude very detailed, site-specific hydrogeologic data in a regional model; and
- The conceptualization of groundwater flow on a regional basis for the purpose of this model (the evaluation of groundwater supply).
Continuing efforts must be made to reduce model uncertainty and increase model uniqueness. As new data are obtained and new understandings of regional hydrogeology evolve, the model will be re-optimized. In particularly, the following types of information will likely have an impact on reducing model uncertainty:
- New estimates of hydraulic conductivity from new pumping tests (expressed as prior knowledge in the model) - Additional calibration data, such as synoptic water levels and baseflow data - Better understanding of the water-transmitting characteristics of the glacial drift deposits - Refined estimates of recharge, particularly leakage from lakes</attraccr> </attracc> <complete>The entire seven county geographic area is covered</complete> <lineage> <procstep> <procdesc>PROCESS: 2030 and 2050 water demand was projected for each municipality or municipal water supply system in the Twin Cities metropolitan area using the method described in Appendix E of the 2009 Metropolitan Council report 'Twin Cities Metropolitan Area Regional Groundwater Flow Model Version 2.00 - Technical Report in Support of the Metropolitan Area Master Water Supply Plan'.
Model results were exported as ESRI Spatial Analyst raster files and used to calculate where the modeled aquifer elevation is less than 50% available head, as defined by:
Projection Year Aquifer Water Elevation - (Calibration Year Aquifer Water Elevation - (50% (Calibration Year Aquifer Water Elevation - Aquifer Bedrock Surface)))
Results were clipped to areas where the aquifer is considered to be currently confined, as defined by:
Aquifer Water Level Elevation - Aquifer Bedrock Surface > 3.048 meters
3. 048 meters was selected instead of 0.000 meters as the threshold to define confined conditions, because it allows for some natural variability in aquifer water levels to cause seasonal shifts from confined to unconfined conditions in areas where existing available head is very small.</procdesc> </procstep>
</lineage> </dataqual> <spdoinfo> <indspref /> <direct>Raster</direct> <mgmg3obj /> <mgmg3til /> </spdoinfo> <distinfo> <distliab>NOTICE: The Geographic Information System (GIS) Data to which this notice is attached are made available pursuant to the Minnesota Government Data Practices Act (Minnesota Statutes Chapter 13). Doing so will tell your browser to download a 'ZIP' file which will contain the following:

This dataset can also be viewed and downloaded from the MetroGIS DataFinder Cafe at http://www.datafinder.org/cafe/ . The Cafe allows users to subset or clip datasets using an existing feature, such as a city or school district boundary or an ad-hoc, user defined area.
Additionally, this dataset is available for direct use via one or more map services. More information about what a web mapping service is can be found at http://www.datafinder.org/services/ .
